summary: This is an email chain from September 2019 between a Wall Street Journal reporter, Davis O'Brien, and an SDNY prosecutor (redacted). O'Brien is seeking guidance on a story about Jeffrey Epstein's charity Gratitude America, its connection to Deutsche Bank, and the scope of the SDNY investigation into Epstein's financial activities and charities.

persons.name: Davis O'Brien
persons.context: Wall Street Journal reporter working on a story about Jeffrey Epstein's charity Gratitude America, its funding from Leon Black's foundation, and its Deutsche Bank account. He is emailing questions to an SDNY prosecutor.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure whose charity, Gratitude America, and financial relationships with banks like Deutsche Bank are under scrutiny by the SDNY. The email discusses his use of the charity to pay fines and its financial transactions.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: His foundation controlled by Apollo granted $10 million to Epstein's charity Gratitude America in 2015, as reported by the journalist.

connections.description: Epstein's charity Gratitude America received a $10 million grant from a foundation controlled by Leon Black in 2015.
O'Brien is a reporter investigating and writing a story about Epstein's financial activities and charities.

events.title: SDNY Investigation into Epstein's Finances
events.description: O'Brien's email indicates the SDNY investigation into Epstein is ongoing and may be expanding to scrutinize his financial relationships with banks (like Deutsche Bank) and his nonprofit foundations.

keyFacts: Epstein's Virgin Islands-based charity, Gratitude America, received a $10 million grant in 2015 from a foundation controlled by Apollo co-founder Leon Black.
Gratitude America listed donations on its tax forms (2016-2017) that were never received by the named charities.
Epstein attempted to use the Gratitude America charity to pay fines in the Virgin Islands.
Gratitude America held an account at Deutsche Bank, and the SDNY was scrutinizing Epstein's relationship with the bank.
The SDNY investigation into Epstein in September 2019 was potentially expanding beyond sex-trafficking to include financial wrongdoing, charities, and tax filings.
